will vectorize them and then by scanning through a large corpus of text you'll
begin to find factors that are similar to each other now there's a lot approaches to this particular problem

the semantics of the underlying data by placing those similar items closer
together and those that that proximity can be measured so Amazon's the
architecture of object Tyvek really consists of these main components first
of all there's two input channels these input channels take object pairs of the
same or different types as inputs and pass them two independent customizable encoders so these could be sequence
pairs token pairs etc then we have two encoders the encoders convert each
object into a fixed length embedding vector then we have what we call a
comparator that compares the embeddings in different ways and creates outputs or
scores that correspond to the strengths of relation of the relationship between
each of these objects so an example of the output score could be one right it's
like a hundred percent it indicates that there's a very strong relationship between the pair it's more likely to be
something you know something in between one and zero so what are the use cases
